Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Bayesian Network Estimation across Multiple Sample Groups and Data Types
Award.AbstractNarration:
As part of this collaborative research, the investigators will develop new statistical methods for the estimation of multiple graphical networks. The proposed research will address the challenge of learning networks when there is heterogeneity among both the subjects and the variables considered, breaking new ground in graphical modeling and Bayesian statistics. The methods developed will have the potential for significant impact in statistics and in applied fields in which problems of network estimation naturally arise. In particular, applications in neuroimaging will be explored. The project will include educational and training activities for graduate students. Findings will be disseminated to the research community and used to further interdisciplinary collaborative efforts. Software and code will be developed and deposited in public repositories.

When all samples are collected under similar conditions or reflect a single type of disease, methods such as the graphical lasso or Bayesian network inference approaches can be applied to learn the underlying conditional dependence relations. In many studies, however, samples are obtained for different subtypes or disease, under varying experimental settings, or other heterogeneous conditions. The challenge becomes even more formidable when multiple data types are under consideration. This project will focus on the development of Bayesian methods to learn networks for a single data type across multiple sample groups using an approach that both links edge values across groups, and flexibly models which groups are most similar. Methods will also be extended to a hierarchical modeling framework of networks from both heterogeneous sets of subjects and heterogeneous data types.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Network inference refers to identifying dependence relations between variables in high-dimensional data. The motivation for network inference is to identify normal functional relations, and to characterize how these relations are perturbed in different settings, such as varying treatment conditions or environments; this allows the identification of potential points of intervention. There may also be interest in integrating several types of data; for example, each subject may be profiled using multiple platforms such as genomic, proteomic, and imaging technologies. Under this award, we have proposed methods that address challenges in network inference from high-dimensional data, and applied them to real data derived from genomic, neuroimaging, and microbiome studies.

To address the need for approaches that can handle data observed from multiple modalities, we proposed a statistical method that improves how well we can learn biological networks across multiple data types, and applied this approach to identify transcriptomic and metabolomic mechanisms underlying chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Since many features observed in both omics and imaging data do not meet standard assumptions of normality, we then developed a network inference method that allows the variables to follow more flexible distributions. We applied this approach to illustrate the relationships among features derived from tumor images.

For the setting where there are multiple sample groups, such as subjects with varying disease stages, we proposed a new modeling approach that allows us to learn a network specific to each sample group, while simultaneously linking the strength of network edges across groups. This approach allows us to more accurately identify differential network connections across groups as compared to existing network inference methods. We applied this model to pinpoint changes in structural connectivity in the brain during the progression of Alzheimer's disease. Finally, we have developed an efficient method for the simultaneous inference of networks for count-based data and the selection of important covariates that influence the abundance of the observed counts. We have applied this method to characterize the relation between vaginal microbiome profiles and cytokine profiles collected from pregnant women as part of a study on pre-term birth.

During the project time period, we have co-advised a PhD student, who contributed substantially to the research and has successfully defended his doctoral thesis in Statistics from Rice University. We have also presented our research at national conferences including ENAR and JSM. Additional PhD students have been involved in aspects of our research and appear as co-authors on all publications.

These projects demonstrate broader impacts, both in terms of the statistical models developed (which can be applied to scientific studies in the future), and the specific conclusions we have identified in our applications. We have developed well-documented code along with our methods, which is freely available online. In particular, for our project on estimation of multiple graphs with related edge values, we provide R and Matlab code at https://github.com/cbpeterson/Linked_precision_matrices. For our project on the simultaneous selection of network and covariates, we provide Python code at https://github.com/Nathan-Osborne/SINC/.  In terms of scientific conclusions, our study on structural connectivity in Alzheimer's identified decreased connectivity in the occipital lobe as a biomarker of disease progression, and our study on the vaginal microbiome in pregnancy found that microorganism from the genus Lactobacillus formed their own subnetwork, and showed more dependence on host cytokine levels than other microbiome features. In addition, our engagement with PhD students and successful mentorship reflects our commitment to education and training. Finally, all projects represent collaborations across multiple institutions.
